# [9.1 General Properties of the Moon](https://openstax.org/books/astronomy-2e/pages/9-1-general-properties-of-the-moon)

# {background-image="figures/09/old11-pg_0006.svg" background-size="75%"}

# Apollo Flights {.smaller}

|Flight|Date|Main Accomplishment|
|------|----|-------------------|
|Apollo 8|Dec. 1968|First humans to fly around the Moon|
|Apollo 10|May 1969|First spacecraft rendezvous in lunar orbit|
|Apollo 11|July 1969|First human landing; 22 kg of samples returned|
|Apollo 12|Nov. 1969|First Apollo Lunar Surface Experiment Package (ALSEP); visit to Surveyor 3 lander|
|Apollo 13|Apr. 1970|Landing aborted due to explosion in service module|
|Apollo 14|Jan. 1971|First “rickshaw” on the Moon|
|Apollo 15|July 1971|First “rover” visit; astronauts traveled 24 km|
|Apollo 16|Apr. 1972|First landing in highlands; 95 kg of samples returned|
|Apollo 17|Dec. 1972|Geologist among the crew; 111 kg  of samples returned|

# Apollo Missions Accomplishments


:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="45%"}
1. Collected nearly 400 kg of lunar samples
2. Deploy *A*pollo *L*unar *S*urface *E*xperiment *P*ackages (ALSEP)
3. Command Modules photograph and analyze lunar surface

# [9.4 The Origin of the Moon](https://openstax.org/books/astronomy-2e/pages/9-4-the-origin-of-the-moon)

# {background-image="figures/09/old11-pg_0007.svg" background-size="75%"}

# Fission Theory

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="45%"}
- Proposed by George Darwin in 1879
- Rapidly spinning Earth expelled the Moon’s mass
- Modern calculations discredit this idea
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
![[Rapidly Spinning Earth Ejecting lunar mass](https://www.space.fm/astronomy/earthmoonsun/moonorigins.html) ](figures/09/anim_origins2.gif){#fig-fission-theory fig-align="center"}
::: 
:::
::::
 
# Sister Theory

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="45%"}
- Also known as the Accretion theory
- Earth and Moon formed simultaneously from accretion disk
- Cannot explain angular momentum of Earth-Moon
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
![[Earth and Moon coalesce from the same material](https://www.space.fm/astronomy/earthmoonsun/moonorigins.html) ](figures/09/anim_origins1.gif){#fig-fission-theory fig-align="center"}
::: 
:::
::::
 
# Capture Theory

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="45%"}
- Explains tidal locking of Earth and Moon
- How did the “protomoon” lose enough kinetic energy to be captured
- Can’t explain compositional similarities of Earth and Moon
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
![[Moon caught in Earth's gravitational field.](https://www.space.fm/astronomy/earthmoonsun/moonorigins.html) ](figures/09/anim_origins3.gif){#fig-fission-theory fig-align="center"}
::: 
:::
::::
 
# Giant Impact Theory

Currently accepted model

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="45%"}
- Mars size object impacted 
- Explains some compositional similarities of Earth and Moon
- Explains tidal locking of Earth and Moon
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
![[Stable isotope ratios of lunar and terrestrial rocks suggest common origin.](https://www.space.fm/astronomy/earthmoonsun/moonorigins.html) ](figures/09/anim_origins4.gif){#fig-fission-theory fig-align="center"}
::: 
:::
